subject: RE: [junit] Looking for some "Best Practices"

messageBody:
--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>
wrote:
>
> You probably want something similar to
> CruiseControl. If you don't know
> about it, Google it, download it and try it. It's
> not quite what you
> want, but it can be used to build and test your
> product every 'n'
> minutes, and only if there has been CVS activity in
> the meantime.

Actually I already use CruiseControl and you are
correct it is not quite what I had in mind.

The scenario I am most interested in is a single
developer working on a small section of the code on
his/her own machine. They want to run tests regularly,
during development, but why should they run the whole
suite every time, when they are only changing a small
section. The time it takes to do a test run is one of
the major hurdles to getting developers to run the
tests in the first place.

This "test filtering" could be acheived by writing
TestSuite classes in JUnit - but I personally think
this is a little clumsy, static, error prone and takes
extra development time we just don't have. We use the
batchtest task from Ant for our JUnit tests - but of
course it runs all of our tests every time. What we
really need is an extension to the batchtest task that
can do more complex filtering - not just by class
names - to decide what tests to run. I think that one
of the most useful filters would be to only run tests
that relate to code the developer has changed in the
last 10 minutes (or some other number). There are
probably other ones.

Of course, when the developer is ready to check in
their code, they turn off the filters and run the
whole suite.
